May 1917.SECRET.WAR CABINET, 147.Minutes of a Meeting of the War Cabinet, held in London at 10, Downing Street, S.W.,on Friday, May 25, 1917, at 3%30 p.m.Present:The Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. the Viscount Milner,G.C.B., G.C.M.G.The Right Hon. G. N. Barnes, M.P.The following were also presentThe Right Hon. Lord Robert Cecil, K.C.,M.P., Acting Secretary of State forForeign Affairs.The Right Hon. the Earl oe Derby,KG., G.C.V.O., C.B., Secretary of Statefor War.General Sir W. R. Robertson, G.C.B.,K.C.V.O., D.S.O., Chief of the ImperialGeneral Staff.The Right Hon. C. Addison, M.D., M.P.,Minister of Munitions.The Right Hon. Sir E. Carson, K.C.,M.P., First Lord of the Admiralty.Admiral Sir J. R. Jellicoe, G.C.B., O.M.,G.C.V.O., First Sea Lord of theAdmiralty.Vice-Admiral Sir Eric Geddes, controller,Admiralty.Lieutenant-Colonel Sir M. P. A. Hankey, K.C.B., Secretary.Fleet Paymaster P. H. Row, R.N., Assistant Secretary.Mr. Thomas Jones, Assistant Secretary.Ammunition for.J.a^: 1. THE Chief of the Imperial General Staff stated that ar-ieict bruns and communication had reached him from the Italian Ambassadorrequesting that the supply of heavy artillery ammunition and field guns should be expedited as much as possible, and pointed out thatwe were giving them all the heavy ammunition we could, and thatany delay was entirely due to railway transport difficulties inFrance. He gathered that a similar communication had been addressed to the French Government, and that the Italians were really anxious to obtain the field guns from that source.The Chief of the Imperial General Staff undertook to bring thematter forward for consideration at the forthcomingAnglo-French Conference. The Italian Front. 2. The Chief of the Imperial General Staff informed the War Cabinet that the Italians had taken 18,000 prisoners in the last ten days, that their left flank had not progressed as well as might have w!)been hoped, but that the general results were satisfactory. It Avasestimated that the total Italian casualties since the offensive beganmight reach 60,000. *The War Cabinet decided that The Foreign Office should send a telegram from the BritishGovernment to the Italian Government congratulating thelatter on the success of their offensive, and that theSecretary of State for War should send a similar telegram to the Italian Minister for War.Submarines. 3. The First Sea Lord reported that (a.) The special service ship " Merops " had engaged an enemy submarine and sunk her, and had herself sustained only two casualties, both men being slightly wounded.(6.) A French submarine had sunk an enemy submarine in theMediterranean.(c.) H.M.S. " Glen" had sunk a submarine by gunfire.(d.) An " America " seaplane had also sunk a submarine.The two latter have already been reported to the War cabinet as probable losses.Adriatic :Attack onAerodrome.4. The First Sea Lord reported that the monitors " Earl ofPeterborough" and "Sir Thomas Picton" had bombarded theProsino aerodrome in the Adriatic.Seaplane attack 5- The First Sea Lord reported ^ an engagement between aon Zeppelin. seaplane and a Zeppelin off Terschelling, but that the latter had escaped by taking advantage of the clouds prevalent at the time.6. The First Sea Lord gave the following information whichhad been obtained in connection with submarines from the captain of the German submarine U. 93, who stated that the whole of the shipbuilding resources of Germany were now concentrated on thebuilding of submarines ; that the output would eventually reach20 a month ; that there were approximately 300 German submarinesnow in commission ; that there were no difficulties as regardsobtaining crews for these submarines, which were taken from themen of the High Sea Fleet, trained in a special school for twomonths, and after a three weeks' submarine cruise the men were considered competent.Mammoth Ships. 7. The First Sea Lord stated that, from enquiries made in theUnited States of America it appeared that Newport News was theonly yard capable of building mammoth ships, and that it wouldtake IS months to lay clown the necessary plant, after which itwould take a year to build such a ship there.Sir Eric geddes stated that he was going into the question ofbuilding mammoth ships in the United Kingdom, and would reportto the War Cabinet as soon as his enquiries were complete.german submarines :Building andManning. H.M.S. " Hilary." ^ 8. The First Sea Lord stated that the armed mercantile cruiser" Hilary " had been hit by a torpedo this morning in the vicinity of( y the Faroe Islands, but at noon was still afloat and steaming 9 knots.German Mercantile 9. The Prime Minister brought to the notice of the WarRotterdam Cabinet a report that German coal ships were using Rotterdam.' ' The First Sea Lord stated that the Admiralty were aware of this information, but that no steps could be taken to prevent such tradesave by violating Dutch, Danish, and Scandinavian territorial waters.british representation inthe United Statesof America.10. With reference to War Cabinet 136, Minute 17, the WarCabinet noted that Mr. Balfour had asked that the question of any alteration in British diplomatic representation in the United states might be postponed until his return to England.The War Cabinet decided, however, that this need not debar adecision with regard to a business man being appointed as the Headof all the Missions representing the different Departments concerned,such as the Admiralty, the War Office, the Ministry of Munitions,the Shipping Controller, and the Food Controller.It was pointed out that these Missions were at present withouta responsible Head, with the result that there was some conflict of interests, and that, by co-ordinating their action, thus preventingoverlapping and one Department bidding against another, far betterresults might be expected to ensue. Although the person selectedwould no doubt have a great deal to do with Americans, his primarydirty would be to control our own operations, including recruiting,production, purchase, manufactures, transport, and the priority ofthe various claims.Lord Robert Cecil pointed out the desirability of consulting-Mr. Balfour before any definite appointment was made, so thatwhoever was selected might be acceptable to the Americans ; other-wise harm might result.Those Heads of Departments concerned wdio were present, were of opinion that Lord Northeliffe might be a very suitable person forthis appointment, and the War Cabinet decided that The Chief of the Imperial General Staff should draft a telegram,giving fully the whole situation and the desirability of suchan appointment, and forward the same to the Acting-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, who was requestedto transmit the telegram to the British Ambassador atWashington as well as to Mr. Balfour, and ask for an earlyexpression of their views on the proposed appointment.ForthcomingSocialist andDemocraticConference atLeeds.m11. The Prime Minister informed the War Cabinet that his attention had been drawn to an advertisement which had been published in the " Daily News," which indicated that a large Labour,Socialistic, and Democratic Conference would be held at the AlbertHall, Leeds, on Sunday, the 3rd June, with a view, inter alia, ofestablishing in Great Britain a Council of Workmen's and Soldiers'Delegates, on the lines of the one now in existence in Russia.The War Cabinet were informed that the fact that this conference was proposed to be held was wrell known to the Labourworld, and they decided that It would be undesirable to take any steps to suppress furtheradvertisements, or to prohibit the meeting itself, though itwas of such a revolutionary character. They requested the Secretary of State for War to take the necessary action to ensure that no soldiers in uniform attended theConference.2, Whitehall Gardens, 8.W.,May 25, 1917.
